The '''1997 [[NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament]]''' involved 64 schools playing in [[Single-elimination tournament|single-elimination]] play to determine the national champion of men's [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[college basketball]]. It began on March 13, 1997, and ended with the [[1997 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship Game|championship game]] on March 31 in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] at the [[RCA Dome]]. A total of 63 games were played.

The Final Four consisted of [[1996–97 Kentucky Wildcats men's basketball team|Kentucky]], who entered the tournament as the defending national champions, [[1996–97 Minnesota Golden Gophers men's basketball team|Minnesota]], making their first Final Four appearance, [[1996–97 Arizona Wildcats men's basketball team|Arizona]], making their third Final Four appearance and first since 1994, and [[1996–97 North Carolina Tar Heels men's basketball team|North Carolina]], making their thirteenth Final Four appearance and first since 1995.

In the national championship game, Arizona defeated Kentucky in overtime 84–79 to win their first national championship. For the second time in the last three seasons, the defending national champions reached the final game and lost.

[[Miles Simon]] of [[Arizona Wildcats men's basketball|Arizona]] was named the tournament's [[NCAA basketball tournament Most Outstanding Player|Most Outstanding Player]].

Several years later, [[Minnesota Golden Gophers men's basketball|Minnesota]] was stripped of its [[Final Four]] appearance following the discovery of NCAA academic rule violations. In addition, the Gophers were stripped of their [[Big Ten]] title they had also won.<ref>{{cite web |title=Minnesota Stripped Of Conference Championship |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/minnesota-stripped-of-conference-championship/ |website=CBS News |access-date=October 25, 2021 |date=November 21, 2000}}</ref>

[[University of Arizona|Arizona]] also became the only school since the introduction of the 64-team bracket in 1985,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ncaa.com/news/basketball-men/2010-01-28/bracket-question |title=Bracket Question |access-date=2018-04-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304115254/http://www.ncaa.com/news/basketball-men/2010-01-28/bracket-question |archive-date=2016-03-04 |url-status=dead }}</ref> to defeat three number 1 seeds in the tournament, having upset overall number one seed [[1996–97 Kansas Jayhawks men's basketball team|Kansas]] in addition to their two Final Four victories.

The tournament also saw the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship upsets|third victory by a #15 seed over a #2 seed]], as [[1996–97 Coppin State Eagles men's basketball team|Coppin State]] defeated [[1996–97 South Carolina Gamecocks men's basketball team|South Carolina]] in their first round matchup. In addition, a #14 seed advanced to the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|Sweet Sixteen]] for only the second time, as Southeast Region #14 seed [[1996–97 Chattanooga Mocs basketball team|Chattanooga]] defeated both [[Georgia Bulldogs men's basketball|Georgia]] and [[1996–97 Illinois Fighting Illini men's basketball team|Illinois]].

The tournament marked the end of the career of North Carolina coach [[Dean Smith]]. Smith, whose team lost in the national semifinals, retired just prior to the beginning of the 1997–98 season.

The following are the sites that were selected to host each round of the 1997 tournament:

'''First and Second Rounds'''
*March 13 and 15
**'''East Region'''
*** [[Lawrence Joel Veterans Memorial Coliseum]], [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina]] (Host: [[Wake Forest University]])
**'''Midwest Region'''
*** [[The Palace of Auburn Hills]], [[Auburn Hills, Michigan]] (Host: [[Mid-American Conference]])
**'''Southeast Region'''
*** [[Memphis Pyramid]], [[Memphis, Tennessee]] (Host: [[University of Memphis]])
**'''West Region'''
*** [[Jon M. Huntsman Center]], [[Salt Lake City|Salt Lake City, Utah]] (Host: [[University of Utah]])
*March 14 and 16
**'''East Region'''
*** [[Civic Arena (Pittsburgh)|Pittsburgh Civic Arena]], [[Pittsburgh|Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] (Host: [[Duquesne University]])
**'''Midwest Region'''
*** [[Kemper Arena]], [[Kansas City, Missouri]] (Host: [[University of Kansas]])
**'''Southeast Region'''
*** [[Charlotte Coliseum]], [[Charlotte, North Carolina]] (Host: [[Davidson College]])
**'''West Region'''
*** [[McKale Center]], [[Tucson, Arizona]] (Host: [[University of Arizona]])

'''Regional semifinals and finals''' (Sweet Sixteen and Elite Eight)
*March 20 and 22
**'''Midwest Regional''', [[Alamodome]], [[San Antonio|San Antonio, Texas]] (Host: [[University of Texas at San Antonio]])
**'''West Regional''', [[SAP Center|San Jose Arena]], [[San Jose, California]] (Host: [[San Jose State University]])
*March 21 and 23
**'''East Regional''', [[Carrier Dome]], [[Syracuse, New York]] (Host: [[Syracuse University]])
**'''Southeast Regional''', [[Legacy Arena|BJCC Coliseum]], [[Birmingham, Alabama]] (Host: [[Southeastern Conference]])

'''National semifinals and championship''' (Final Four and championship)
*March 29 and 31
**[[RCA Dome]], [[Indianapolis|Indianapolis, Indiana]] (Hosts: [[Butler University]], [[Midwestern Collegiate Conference]])

==Teams==
There were 30 automatic bids awarded to the tournament - of these, 27 were given to the winners of their conference's tournament, while three were awarded to the team with the best regular-season record in their conference ([[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]], [[Ivy League]] and [[Pac-12 Conference|Pac-10]]).

Two conference champions made their first NCAA tournament appearances: [[1996–97 Charleston Southern Buccaneers men's basketball team|Charleston Southern]] ([[Big South Conference|Big South]]) and [[1996–97 Jackson State Tigers basketball team|Jackson State]] ([[Southwestern Athletic Conference|SWAC]]).

Minnesota vacated all NCAA tournament wins from the 1996–97 season due to an [[University of Minnesota basketball scandal|academic fraud scandal]]. Unlike forfeiture, a vacated game does not result in the other school being credited with a win, only with Minnesota removing the wins from its own record.

==Announcers==
*[[Bob Carpenter (sportscaster)|Bob Carpenter]] or [[Jim Nantz]]/[[Billy Packer]]/[[Craig James (running back)|Craig James]] – First & Second Round at Tucson, Arizona; Southeast Regional at Birmingham, Alabama; Final Four at Indianapolis, Indiana
**Carpenter called the first-round games at Tucson.
*[[Sean McDonough]]/[[Bill Raftery]]/[[Andrea Joyce]] – First & Second Round at Winston-Salem, North Carolina; West Regional at San Jose, California
*[[Tim Ryan (sportscaster)|Tim Ryan]]/[[Al McGuire]]/[[Michele Tafoya]] – First & Second Round at Memphis, Tennessee; Midwest Regional at San Antonio, Texas
*[[Gus Johnson (sportscaster)|Gus Johnson]] and [[Quinn Buckner]] – First & Second Round at Auburn Hills, Michigan; East Regional at Syracuse, New York
*[[Tim Brando]] and [[George Raveling]] – First & Second Round at Charlotte, North Carolina
*[[Mike Gorman]] and [[Jon Sundvold]] – First & Second Round at Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania
*[[Ted Robinson (sportscaster)|Ted Robinson]] and [[Derrek Dickey]] – First & Second Round at Kansas City, Missouri
*[[Gary Thorne]]/[[Dan Bonner]]/[[Mike Mayock]] – First & Second Round at Salt Lake City, Utah

[[Pat O'Brien (radio and television personality)|Pat O'Brien]] and Jim Nantz respectively served as the first round afternoon and evening studio hosts, joined by analyst [[Clark Kellogg]].
